The technique of directly comparing against a 'gold standard' mentioned
above works for simple cases but is not adequate for complex cases or cases
where it is not practical to compare the entire set of substates of the
returned object.

In Test Mentor (a commercial component testing tool) we supply two
mechanisms for arbitrary object validation beyond the normal JUnit-like
assertion methods:

1) An extendable hierarchy of reusable test components that represent
specific object comparison strategies. For example, the very simplest
comparison uses object1.equals(object2). More complex strategies might
intelligently validate according to various constraints, perform conversions
first such as folding Strings to upper case or comparing the toString() form
of objects, use fuzzy logic, etc.

2) Reusable test components or methods that represent strategies for
recursively traversing and extracting object states. These can be applied to
objects under test to extract just those states (instance variables) within
an object or cluster of objects that are of interest in a particular
comparison, and compare them to gold standard versions of those objects. In
other words these test components represent 'views' on an object or cluster
of objects.

So the idea behind the above is to make the notion of validation an easily
documented, reusable, sharable, extendable component. Although this is
provided as part of Test Mentor's execution framework and automated test
generation, there's no reason these principles couldn't be applied to any
JUnit test with a little work. This scheme was presented as a general unit
testing practice at JavaOne last year
(http://jsp.java.sun.com/javaone/javaone2000/pdfs/TS-708.pdf) so its fairly
generic.
